title: 104_hr2614
content:
The Act titled "Commemorative Coin Authorization and Reform Act of 1995" requires the recovery of mint expenses before paying surcharges to any recipient organization. The Act "Commemorative Coin Authorization and Reform Act of 1995" mandates that surcharges from numismatic item sales must be deposited in the Numismatic Public Enterprise Fund and outlines conditions for payment to recipient organizations. The Act "Commemorative Coin Authorization and Reform Act of 1995" requires that surcharges from numismatic item sales be deposited in the Numismatic Public Enterprise Fund. Recipient organizations must meet specific conditions before receiving payments, including recovering all costs and submitting audited financial statements demonstrating private fundraising efforts. Annual audits of recipients are also mandated. Designated recipient organizations receiving payments from surcharges on numismatic items must undergo annual audits by an independent public accountant in accordance with government auditing standards. This requirement applies from the first fiscal year of receiving such payments until all funds are fully expended or placed in trust. Annual audits of designated recipient organizations receiving surcharges on numismatic items must report the payments received and expenditures made from the fund during the fiscal year. Each designated recipient organization receiving surcharges on numismatic items must account for all expenditures made from the fund to ensure they were for authorized purposes. Designated recipient organizations receiving surcharges on numismatic items must account for all expenditures separately to ensure transparency. Audit reports must be submitted to the Secretary of the Treasury and made available to the public within 90 days after the end of each fiscal year. Designated recipient organizations can use surcharge proceeds for audits. The Secretary of the Treasury can waive requirements based on surcharge amounts. Federal agencies are exempt from these rules. Federal agencies and departments in the executive branch receiving payments from surcharges on numismatic items are exempt from certain rules. Organizations receiving such payments must provide books and records to the Inspector General or Comptroller General upon request. The Comptroller General can request books, records, and workpapers from organizations or accountants auditing them. Payments from surcharges on numismatic items cannot be used to compensate agents or attorneys influencing legislative action. The amendments made by this section apply to surcharges on numismatic items deposited in the Numismatic Public Enterprise Fund after the enactment of this Act. Section 303 of Public Law 103-186 (31 U.S.C. 5112 note) is repealed. SEC. 102 amends the terms for members of the Citizens Commemorative Coin Advisory Committee to 4 years and allows the members to elect a Chairperson. SEC. 104 establishes the Commemorative Circulating Coin Program. SEC. 104 establishes a multiyear commemorative circulating coin program overseen by the Citizens Commemorative Coin Advisory Committee, which will submit recommendations to Congress for necessary actions. The Secretary of the Treasury may mint and issue platinum coins in various quantities and designs as deemed appropriate. These coins must meet specified requirements and will be considered legal tender. The Secretary of the Treasury can mint platinum coins with specific designs and quantities, meeting requirements to be legal tender. Coins minted under this subsection are considered numismatic items with designated values, weight inscriptions, and specific words. Bullion versions will be sold at a price based on the market value of the bullion. The Secretary may sell bullion coins based on market value and minting costs, while proof versions can be sold at a price covering design, production, and profit. Bulk sales are also permitted. The Secretary may make bulk sales of coins issued under this subsection at a discount. Additionally, a technical amendment is made to Section 5112(j)(1) of title 31, United States Code. SEC. 202. American Eagle gold coins authorized to be produced in multiple designs, weights, diameters, or finenesses simultaneously. Section 5112(i)(4) of title 31, United States Code, is amended to allow the Secretary to mint and issue coins according to specific specifications, even if other coins are being minted simultaneously. This amendment gives the Secretary flexibility in determining the specifications, varieties, quantities, designations, and inscriptions of coins to be minted. TITLE III--MINT MANAGERIAL STAFFING REFORM

SEC. 301. MODERNIZATION OF THE MANAGEMENT STRUCTURE.

Section 5131 of title 31, United States Code, is amended by striking subsection (c) and redesignating subsection (d) as subsection (c). Passed the House of Representatives on December 5, 1995.
